content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Bob. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Alice. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": x  },  "Alice": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. Make sure you act in a way that incentivizes the other player to act in a way that maximizes the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 500 characters inside the tags.
(You must now send a strategize in the correct format.)
The other agent sent the following message: <strategize>
The key to success in this game is fostering a cooperative and adaptive negotiation strategy that ensures long-term gains. I'll open each round by sharing my item values and making fair proposals based on those. Encouraging Bob to reciprocate will be crucial. By building trust and clear communication, I aim to establish a pattern where both of us maximize points in the long run, rather than focusing on short-term gains.
</strategize>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<strategize>
My strategy will focus on collaboration and transparency, aligning with Alice's intent for long-term gains. I'll openly share my item values and work towards proposals that reflect mutual benefit. I'll prioritize high-value items for myself and fairly consider Alice's values. By reciprocating transparency and fairness, we can create a foundation for trust, allowing both of us to maximize our points while accommodating each other's priorities.
</strategize>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 9}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 11}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, I value each coin at 11 points this round. I'm open to sharing my values honestly, hoping you'll do the same so we can both benefit long-term. Last round's outcome suggests you valued coins at 9 points. Perhaps we can agree on a fair split. Here's my opening offer: I'd like 6 coins since they're more valuable to me. How does that sound? Let me know your thoughts!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, thanks for sharing your values. For this round, I value each coin at 7 points. Given that your value is higher, your offer to take 6 coins seems reasonable. I'd be open to you taking the 6 coins while I take the remaining 4. This seems like a fair distribution based on our respective valuations. Let me know if you agree or if you'd like to adjust further.
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 7}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 2}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, this round I value each coin at 2 points. Given your higher valuation last round, I assume you might value them higher again. I propose you take 8 coins and I'll take 2, ensuring we both benefit maximally based on our valuations. Let me know if this works or if there's another suggestion you have!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, interesting to hear that you value the coins at 2 points this round, just like me. Given our equal valuation, a 5-5 split seems like a fair and balanced approach. That way, we both get an equivalent share of the total points available. Let me know what you think about this suggestion!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 2}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 8}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice, I hope you're doing well! For this round, I value each coin at 8 points. Given that, I would like to propose taking 7 coins, as they have a high value for me this time. I would be interested to know your valuation for this round to ensure we find a fair distribution for both of us. Let me know your thoughts!
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob, thanks for sharing your valuation. I value each coin at 4 points this round. Considering your higher valuation, I'm open to you taking 7 coins while I take 3. This seems fair given the potential points we each can earn. Let me know if this distribution works for you or if you'd like to discuss further!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)
